fields.description:
On page http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/index.html it says "See the respective install guides for Tomcat 5.5.x, Tomcat 5.0.x, Tomcat 4.1.x and Tomcat 4.0.x." 
The Tomcat 5.5.x link leads to http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/tomcat50.html instead of http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/tomcat55.html .
fields.summary: Wrong Link in Documentation

fields.description:
The link to create a sub-task on the left-hand side of the page is

_Create_ sub-task

By putting the emphasis on the _Create_, it de-emphasises "sub-task", and makes it harder to find the sub-task link in the list. The link should probably be:

Create _Sub-task_
fields.summary: Sub-task link obscures its function

fields.description: The urls for Filter Issue Navigator Columns direct to User Issue Navigator Columns. This means you cannot configure filter column order.

Add anchors to the "Manage Versions" page to return to the correct version on the page

fields.description: This means that when you print landscape, it doesn't take the full width.

fields.description:
When doing a quick search and some of the terms are recognised for smart querying a message box is drawn giving the user the option to rerun the qury without any smartness. Need to ensure the query uses a POST request (use javascript to submit form).

Also a good idea is to include an "info" icon on the box such that it is more noticable.
fields.summary: Rewrite the smart query message box to use POST requests

fields.description: Some of the jars are actually packaged up in the lib directory of the source build. This was before the attlasian repository came on line. Need to change the build such that no libs are packaged to reduce the size of the source download.
fields.summary: Remove dependencies from the lib directory of the source build

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Browsing one of these pages will clear the default value: 
* <context_path>/secure/admin/MakeDefaultIssueType.jspa
* <context_path>/secure/admin/MakeDefaultResolution.jspa
* <context_path>/secure/admin/MakeDefaultPriority.jspa

h3. Suggested Solution
According to [RFC 2616|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616]:
{quote}
9.1.1 Safe Methods
   ...
   In particular, the convention has been established that the GET and
   HEAD methods SHOULD NOT have the significance of taking an action
   other than retrieval. These methods ought to be considered "safe".
   This allows user agents to represent other methods, such as POST, PUT
   and DELETE, in a special way, so that the user is made aware of the
   fact that a possibly unsafe action is being requested.
{quote}

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: HTTP GETs should not update data (resolution, issue type, priority, ...)

fields.description:
Reindexing can take a long time if the Users have not been loaded

The much improved reindexer loses much of its new found pace if the users have not be loaded into the system yet. You can get around this problem by going to the Users Broswer admin page and then starting the reindex.

This is caused by the users cache not being sysnchronised and thus when the multi-threaded issues reindexer hits the cache for the first time, all threads will try to populate the cache.
fields.summary: Reindexing can take a long time if the Users have not been previously loaded

fields.description:
There needs to be some way to enforce user passwords to meet some minimum complexity requirements.  At the moment there doesn't seem to be any way to do this other then by using an external LDAP authenticator.  Unfortunately jira does not seem to be able to allow users to change their passwords on the external LDAP system. 

Another feature would be the ability to expire user passwords after a given time requireing them to enter a new one.
fields.summary: Enforce Password Complexity
Add Link header for pages with RSS content

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6609].
  {panel}

We would like to be able to have all the release notes of all versions (archived and non-archived) in a single text file.

Is it possible to add an option to /secure/ConfigureReleaseNote.jspa so that we can select 
 "All release notes (archived and non-archived)" and "All release notes (non-archived)". Those options will then need to iterate over all (non)archived releases and display their release notes.

We currently do this manually, because we want to store our release notes in our CVS-server. That makes it very easy to be able to check whether an issue was resolved at the time a release was build. 

Please also make it possible to be able to script it, so that we can integrate in our Ant buildfiles (e.g. use a URL such as:
https://foo.bar/secure/ConfigureReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=ALLRELEASEDVERSIONS).

We would really like this feature, and I don't think it's hard to implement for you guys.

Regards,

Pieter
fields.summary: Display all release notes in text or html

fields.description:
When using Firefox, the workflow action shortcuts (i.e. ALT+1 for first available workflow action) clashes with the Firefox 'Tab' navigation feature (i.e. ALT+1 takes you to the first open tab in a browser window). 

In this case, the user is presented with the first tab, while the first workflow action is executed for the issue. The user may not be aware that this has occured due to the switch in focus.
fields.summary: Workflow action shortcuts clash with Firefox "Tab" navigation.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6601].
  {panel}

Currently we get the NodeAssociations from the database for each issue for every association.  However, it may be useful to get these all in one database call.

We can cache them in a ThreadLocal, so that subsequent hits to the NodeAssociationManager doesn't incur the database hit.  This may also reduce the need for the IssueCache.

From the current entities that we store in that table, it would make sense to cache them all:

insomniac=# select distinct source_node_entity from nodeassociation ;
 source_node_entity
--------------------
 Issue
 Project
(2 rows)
 
insomniac=# select distinct sink_node_entity from nodeassociation ;
   sink_node_entity
-----------------------
 Component
 IssueTypeScreenScheme
 NotificationScheme
 PermissionScheme
 Version
(5 rows)
 
insomniac=# select distinct association_type from nodeassociation ;
 association_type
------------------
 IssueComponent
 IssueFixVersion
 IssueVersion
 ProjectScheme


We should also bound this cache, so that in any thread that hits lots of NodeAssociations, we don't load them all into memory.
fields.summary: Eagerly Cache NodeAssociations

fields.description:
The minRatioLimit and maxRatioLimit request parameters are not being added to the XML (RSS) URL.  This is causing the results returned in the "browser" version of the report to not match those of the xml version of the report.

1. Create a new search filter with the min and max values set
2. preview the results by pressing the "view >>" button
3. Take note of the number of issues returned
4. Select the "xml" link to open the RSS version of the report (note the url does not contain the ratio limit request parameters)
5. Observe: the issues are not being filtered based off the estimated vs actual entered in step 1

If you copy the URL and manually add the request parameters the report shows the correct results
fields.summary: Actual Vs Estimated filter are not being added to XML report URL

fields.description:
We have this custom status 'Approved' which has been added in our workflow between 'Resolved' and 'Closed'. One of our user is reporting an inconsistency.

If the issue has the 'Approved' status and is linked in a comment, the link is strike-out properly. If the same issue is linked to another issue (using the Link Issue feature) the link is not strike-out at all.

There is an inconsistency between comment and Issue links.
fields.summary: Inconsistency in issue strike-out
List of filters should show how many issues match each filter

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6595].
  {panel}

Currently, reindexing our server takes a very long time (45mins) - something which I know is being worked on.
But even with this greatly reduced, it still means an outage for Jira - and reindexing during work-hours (if it needs to be done) is quite a problem.

What would be very nice would be to be able to reindex "offline" - ie reindex in such a way that Jira access isnt affected.

Perhaps create a whole new set of indexes in parallel then switch over?
fields.summary: Offline Jira Re-index

I really like the Quick Search magic keywords, but it is very annoying that 'open' is one of them and this is such a common word. I very frequently do a search like:

  "open AND dialog"

and I get a very confusing page back with the following text in red half way down:

  "Could not parse the query text"

I think it would be worth special casing the keyword logic to say that if the query was not parseable when keywords are removed it should probably retry parsing without removing the keywords.
fields.summary: Quick Search cannot understand a query like 'open AND dialog'

fields.description: I like the magic keywords that Quick Search understands but I find that what I always want is to search unresolved issues. I personally think that the 'open' status of an issue is not very interesting, because I always want to see 'in progress' and 'reopened' issues too. What I most want to see is unresolved issues (JRA-6529). I think it would be very helpful to support a new 'unresolved' keyword that behaves the same as the 'open' keyword but filters the list to be only unresolved issues.
fields.summary: Quick Search should support 'unresolved' as a keyword

fields.description:
There are a number of reasons why users need to do a Quick Search:
1. Search the database to see if an issue has already been reported. 
2. Try to find a particular unresolved issue that they want to update and/or work on.
3. Try to find all related unresolved issues so that they can be fixed together.
4. Search for a historical issue because it had interesting comments/details.

I'm sure there are other use cases too, but I believe that in general most searches by most users want to be on unresolved issues. Without this the user ends up with a massive pile of historical issues for every search query, and these issues swamp the interesting ones. I find that every time I do a search I have to scroll through the list on the side to mark that I only want to search unresolved issues.

I believe that Quick Search should be set up to search 'unresolved' issues only by default. I could see that some users might disagree, so this probably should be both a personal and a system-wide setting (where the personal one trumps the system one). Probably this should actually be specified as a filter so that the user can control other aspects (e.g. I only want Quick Search to search issues in the current release).

An alternative to this would be to make it simpler to quickly switch a search to only searching unresolved issues. Currently it is a very tricky step as you have to scroll down to 'Matching resolutions' which is below the fold in the web page. Once you get there you have to scroll the very small list box to 'unresolved'. I think 'unresolved' is the single most useful filter to be able to specify, so it is a shame that it is so hard to find. Maybe it could be a check box at the top of the 'Edit' section: 'search unresolved issues only'.
fields.summary: Quick Search should only search unresolved issues by default

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6528].
  {panel}

A feature that would be very helpful to us would be to have a way to indicate which releases are active, where this would mean that they are currently being worked on. Our workflow is that the team (developers, QA and documentation) are scheduled work to do for a number of forthcoming releases, but most day-to-day activities are meant to be on the current release.

If JIRA supported knowing that a release was 'active' there are a number of useful features that could be implemented:

1. Filters could be implemented to filter out non-active releases (e.g. 'current unresolved issues' would show only unresolved issues assigned to an 'active' release) - see JRA-6527.

2. JIRA could disallow resolving issues to an unreleased and not active release. Often an issue is assigned to a future release but the developer finds that they can fix it early. More often than not the user then resolves the issue as being fixed in this future release, rather than in the upcoming one.

3. When reporting an issue it would be helpful for the 'current' releases to be listed at the top. For a development team, most bugs are found in the release we are currently working on. This is especially true when QAing a candidate release. So it is very annoying that the reporter has to scroll through all of our released versions before getting to the first current release.

I can see that some of these features might need to be configurable as every team has a different workflow. But I think the feature itself would be generally useful.
fields.summary: Support notion of 'active' releases

fields.description:
We have around twenty shared filters implemented now, and most of them are subtle variants on a base filter.

e.g. we have a filter called 'current unresolved issues' which is all unresolved issues in the release we are currently working on. We then have:
  my current unresolved issues
  my team's current unresolved issues
  current unresolved issues due this week
  current unresolved GUI issues
  my current unresolved GUI issues

When we update the definition of 'current unresolved issues' (e.g. we change the 'fix for' field to the new current release) we have to go and update all of the 'sub'-filters.

There are two solutions that would help us here:
 - have a notion of the 'currently active' releases, because then we wouldn't need to keep updating the filter.
 - allow 'my current unresolved issues' to be defined as:
    filter 'current unresolved issues' where user = currentUser
fields.summary: Allow filters to be built upon other shared filters (combined filters)

fields.description:
This has happened to me a couple of times, and I think this would be an excellent improvement.

I have deployed an application (for bugfixes and unplanned enhancements) twice between planned releases, but the items that I have been working on that were released are still marked as being fixed in an upcoming version.

If you could allow users to specify the "fixed" version as an "Unreleased version", then then when a version is released, the system would check through the list of issues to see which ones had "Unreleased" specified as the fixed version and set it to the recently released one.

That way, if I have release version 0.8, and I'm tracking issues to be released in 0.9, and I have a few sudden critical bugs that need to be fixed and released I can slip in version 0.8.1 and release some bug fixes and have anything that was fixed to that point tracked as being fixed in 0.8.1 instead of 0.9.

From an implementation perspective:
Creating or editing an issue: 
Selecting "unreleased version" as the fixed version records fixedVersionId as -1.

Release a version:
When an administrator (or lead) releases a version, loop through issues for the project, if fixedVersionId = -1 then set fixedVersionId = justReleasedVersionId.

Questions or comments: jira@pollensoft.com
fields.summary: Select "Unreleased Versions" assigns fixed version when deploying

fields.description:
While it is possible to create a custom link type for prerequisite/postrequisite issues, it is limited in usefulness by the following:

1)  There is no way to search for issues based on links (eg:  Search for all issues with a prerequisite issue that is/is not resolved)

2)  There is no way to generate a report or gantt chart (MS Project format?) based on those links

3)  It would be ideal if issues had an "active" or "inactive" state beyond the "fix version" roadmap.  We often are entering issues into JIRA that need to be remembered, but not on an employee's active list just yet.  (for now, we have a workaround in a custom priority called "not now".  Surely we can do better!)  In my view, an issue with prerequisites should be considered "active" only if all the prerequisite tasks have been closed.  At that point, a user who searches for issues assigned to them would find a new issue and could react appropriately.
fields.summary: Prerequisite tasks

fields.description: I would love to see a new action for a particular bug--to email the bug to different people.  You would click on the left rail for an option to email this bug to various people. I can always copy and past the url now, but it is very handy to just email from the bug itself, and that bug would be in the content of the email with space to write comments.

fields.description:
Currently these are the performance improvements in 3.2:

- Issue Navigator 
  - sorting is done through Lucene (memory & speed improvement)
  - Bulk Edit of a single page is done through Lucene (memory & speed)
- Browse Project
  - Popular Issues report is now done in Lucene (20 seconds to 2 seconds)
  - Open issues (Components & Versions) are now grouped in Lucene (up to 10x improvement)
- Portlets:
  - Project portlet speed improved through caching (2x improvement)
  - Assigned to me portlet now sorts through Lucene, and only loads the required issues (up to 10x improvement)
  - (todo) Saved Filter & In progress issues still has to be done
fields.summary: Publicise Performance improvements in 3.2

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6495].
  {panel}

To further enhance the ability to organaise issues the following could be done:

1. Items (issues) could be bulk-added to containers.
2. Time estimates for items within a container should automatically be aggregated. For example: If the container holds two tasks with 1 day and 2 days remaining, the container's remaining days should be 3.
3. Reports shouldn't double-count the time estimates of container tasks and the tasks that they contain.
4. You should have the option to manipulate contained items along with their containers. For example, if you change the Fix Version for a container task, all of the contained tasks should optionally be moved to that new Fix Version as well.
5. It would be nice if containers could hold other containers, but first-round usefulness wouldn't depend upon this.
6. It would be nice if there were default searches that would automatically display these roadmap views for a given project, but first-round usefulness wouldn't depend upon this. 

Please vote for the issue and andd any comments that you may have.
fields.summary: Organise issues into containers or queues
Appearance of subtasks in a list of issues is confusing

fields.description: When creating a new subtask, intuitively one would expect that, if the parent tasks is attached to a particular version (affects or fix), then the subtask would inherit that version information.  This does not occur, and instead we find that we have to specifically set the version information in a subtask.  I cannot think of any occasion that a subtask would be affected to a version other than that of the parent task.
fields.summary: Subtasks do not inherit version information from parent task

fields.description: It would be good for the administrator (or some other group specified in the global permissions) to have the ability to un-share a globally shared filter.  At the moment the only way I can see to remove shared filters that shouldn't be there is to contact the author of that filter.
fields.summary: permission to un-share filters
